verses.text: When David had passed a little beyond the summit, Ziba, the servant of Mephibosheth, met him with a pair of saddled donkeys, on which were two hundred loaves of bread, a hundred bunches of raisins, a hundred summer fruits, and a skin of wine.
verses.comment: Ziba reappears, bringing provisions as David flees Jerusalem.

verses.text: The king said to Ziba, 'Why have you brought these?' Ziba answered, 'The donkeys are for the king’s household to ride, the bread and summer fruit are for the young men to eat, and the wine is for those who grow weary in the wilderness to drink.'
verses.comment: Ziba explains the purpose behind his generous offerings.

verses.text: The king said, 'And where is your master’s son?' Ziba said to the king, 'He is staying in Jerusalem, for he said, “Today the house of Israel will restore to me my father’s kingdom.”'
verses.comment: Ziba alleges Mephibosheth hopes to reclaim Saul’s throne.

verses.text: Then the king said to Ziba, 'All that belonged to Mephibosheth is now yours.' Ziba said, 'I pay homage; let me find favor in your eyes, my lord the king.'
verses.comment: David temporarily gives Mephibosheth’s property to Ziba.

verses.text: When King David reached Bahurim, a man from the family of Saul’s house named Shimei son of Gera came out, cursing as he came.
verses.comment: Shimei, a relative of Saul, confronts David.

verses.text: He threw stones at David and at all the servants of King David, even though all the people and all the mighty men were on David’s right and left.
verses.comment: Shimei openly insults David despite being outnumbered.

verses.text: And Shimei said, as he cursed, 'Get out, get out, you man of blood, you worthless man!'
verses.comment: Shimei accuses David of being a murderer and a troublemaker.

verses.text: The LORD has returned on you all the blood of the house of Saul, in whose place you reign, and the LORD has delivered the kingdom into the hand of your son Absalom. See, you are ruined, because you are a man of blood!
verses.comment: Shimei blames David for Saul’s downfall and claims God is judging him.

verses.text: Then Abishai son of Zeruiah said to the king, 'Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Let me go over and cut off his head.'
verses.comment: Abishai wants to retaliate against Shimei.

verses.text: But the king said, 'What have I to do with you, sons of Zeruiah? If he is cursing because the LORD has said to him, “Curse David,” who then shall say, “Why have you done so?”'
verses.comment: David suggests the LORD may have allowed Shimei to curse.

verses.text: David said to Abishai and to all his servants, 'See, my son, who came from my own body, is seeking my life. How much more now may this Benjaminite! Leave him alone, and let him curse, for the LORD has told him to.'
verses.comment: David compares Absalom’s rebellion to Shimei’s cursing.

verses.text: 'It may be that the LORD will look on my affliction and return good to me instead of his cursing today.'
verses.comment: David hopes the LORD will reward his patience.

verses.text: So David and his men went on the way, while Shimei went along the hillside opposite him and cursed as he went, throwing stones at him and flinging dust.
verses.comment: Shimei continues to curse and harass David.

verses.text: The king and all the people who were with him grew weary, and they refreshed themselves there.
verses.comment: David and his party finally stop to rest.

verses.text: Now Absalom and all the men of Israel came to Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him.
verses.comment: Scene shifts from David to Absalom’s arrival in Jerusalem.

verses.text: And when Hushai the Archite, David’s friend, came to Absalom, Hushai said to Absalom, 'Long live the king! Long live the king!'
verses.comment: Hushai feigns loyalty to Absalom.

verses.text: Absalom said to Hushai, 'Is this your loyalty to your friend? Why did you not go with your friend?'
verses.comment: Absalom questions Hushai’s integrity.

verses.text: Hushai said to Absalom, 'No, for whomever the LORD and this people and all the men of Israel choose, his I will be, and with him I will remain.'
verses.comment: Hushai is deliberately ambiguous about his loyalty.

verses.text: And again, 'Whom should I serve? Should it not be his son? As I have served your father, so I will serve you.'
verses.comment: Hushai continues his subtle statement to ingratiate himself with Absalom.

verses.text: Then Absalom said to Ahithophel, 'Give your counsel about what we should do.'
verses.comment: Absalom seeks Ahithophel’s strategic advice.

verses.text: Ahithophel said to Absalom, 'Go in to your father’s concubines, whom he has left to keep the house. Then all Israel will hear that you have made yourself hateful to your father, and the hands of all who are with you will be strengthened.'
verses.comment: Ahithophel counsels a public act to solidify Absalom’s break from David; see also fulfillment of Nathan’s prophecy.

verses.text: So they pitched a tent for Absalom on the roof, and Absalom went in to his father’s concubines in the sight of all Israel.
verses.comment: Public fulfilment of earlier prophecy and a major act of rebellion.

verses.text: Now in those days the counsel Ahithophel gave was as if one inquired at the word of God. So was all the counsel of Ahithophel esteemed, both by David and by Absalom.
verses.comment: Ahithophel’s counsel was extremely highly regarded by everyone.
